File.Title: Cholinergic Projection to the Dorsal Cap of the Inferior Olive of the Rat, Rabbit, and Monkey
File.Authors: N.H. BARMACK, M. FAGERSON, AND P. ERRICO

Abstract.S: ABSTRACT
The inferior olive is divided into several subnuclei that receive specific sensory information.
The caudal dorsal cap of the medial accessory subdivision of the inferior olive receives horizontal optokinetic information from the nucleus of the optic tract.
The immediately subjacent p-nucleus receives vertical vestibular information mediated by a GABAergc pathway originating from the ipsilateral descending and medial vestibular nuclei.
None of the transmitters to the dorsal cap have been identified.
Using choline acetyltransferase (CUT) immunohistochemistry, we have identified a cholinergic pathway that terminates exclusively in the dorsal cap of rats and monkeys.
No other division of the inferior olive received a significant cholinergic innervation.
In the rabbit, immunostaining for ChAT reveals a weaker and more diffuse cholinergic innervation of both the dorsal cap and the subjacent p-nucleus.

In rats and rabbits we injected iontophoretically the orthograde tracer Phaseolus vulgaris Ieucoagglutinin (PHA-L) into the medial and descending vestibular nuclei (MVN, DVN) as well as the nucleus prepositus hypoglossi (NPH) in order to trace the possible origin of the cholinergic projection.
PHA-L injections into the NPH and medial aspect of the MVN labeled terminals within the contralateral dorsal cap.
PHA-L injections in the central and lateral aspects of the MVN as well as the DVN labeled the ipsilateral p-nucleus.

Pressure injections of wheat germ agglutinin-horseradish peroxidase (WGA-HRP) in the caudal dorsal cap of the rabbit inferior olive demonstrated a predominantly contralateral projection to the dorsal cap from the lateral aspect of the NPH.

However, pressure injections of HRP into the caudal dorsal cap combined with ChAT immunohistochemistry in the rabbit demonstrated that most of the neurons of the NPH that projected to the dorsal cap were not cholinergic, and that most of the CUT-positive neurons within the NPH occupied a more ventral location than the neurons within the NPH that were retrogradely labeled from the HRP injection into the contralateral dorsal cap.
In the rat, we made lesions in the MVN, DVN and NPH by injection of ibotenic acid (0.3-0.5 blj, in an attempt to deplete the dorsal cap of the inferior olive of its cholinergic input.
Lesions confined to the NPH and medial aspect of the MVN of the rat caused a loss of ChAT staining in the contralateral dorsal cap.
Lesions placed more laterally within the MVN or DVN failed to deplete ChAT-positive terminals in the contralateral or ipsilateral dorsal caps.
The dorsal cap of the rat and monkey receives a discrete cholinergic projection.
In the rat, this projection originates from the contralateral NPH.
In the rabbit, the caudal inferior olive receives a weak cholinergc projection.
The dorsal cap receives a projection from the contralateral NPH.
However, this projection is mediated by a non-cholinergic transmitter.
a 19% fi'iiileyLiss.
Inc.

Introduction.S: The inferior olivary complex, the exclusive source of climbing fibers to the cerebellum, is characterized by a topographic organization of sensory inputs from visual (Maekawa and Simpson, '73; Alley et al., '75; Frankfurter et al., '76; Weber et al., '78; Maekawa and Takeda, '79; Takeda and Maekawa, '80; Saint-Cyr and Courdle, '82; Kawamura and Onodera, '84; Leonard et al., '88; Kyuhou and Matsuzaki, '911, vestibular (Walberg, '74; Saint-Cyr and Courville, '791, and somatosensory (Martin et al., '75; Berkley and Hand, '78a,b; Gellman et al., '83; Huerta et al., '85; Molinari et al., '91) systems.
One class of visual input originates from the ipsilateral accessory optic system as well as the ipsilateral nucleus of the optic tract.

It consists of physiologically characterized directionally-selective velocity-sensitive visual information and it terminates in the dorsal cap of Kooy and ventrolateral outgrowth of the inferior olive (Kooy, '16; Maekawa and Simpson, '73; Alley et al., '75; Maekawa and Takeda, '79; Takeda and Maekawa, '80; Kawamura and Onodera, '84; Leonard et al., '88).
This class of visual input appears to be organized about a visual coordinate system that is congruent with the axes of rotation of the semicircular canals.
Each axis of rotation is represented in a different rostral-caudal region within the dorsal cap (Leonard et al., '88).

A second visually related input, less well characterized physiologically, originates from the contralateral superior colliculus and terminates within the caudal third of the medial accessory olive just ventral and lateral to the p-nucleus (Frankfurter et al., '76; Weber et al., '78; Saint-Cyr and Courville, '82; Kyuhou and Matsuzaki, '91).
The vestibular input to the inferior olive appears to arise from the ipsilateral medial vestibular and descending vestibular nuclei (MVN, DVN).

This vestibular input terminates in the ipsilateral p-nucleus (Walberg, '74; Saint-Cyr and Courville, '79) and bilaterally in the dorsal medial cell column (Saint-Cyr and Courville, '79) Immunohistochemical investigations have demonstrated that the vestibular input to the p-nucleus is GABAergic (Nelson et al., '86, '89; Fredette and Mugnaini, '91).
The activity of neurons in the p-nucleus of the rabbit is modulated by vestibular stimulation that activates both the vertical semicircular canals and utricular otoliths (Barmack et al., '89).
The polarity of this vestibularly-modulated activity is consistent with the histochemically defined GABAergic vestibulo-olivary pathway.
Activity is decreased during ipsilateral roll and increased during contralateral roll (Barmack et al., '89).

The inferior olive offers an attractive opportunity for studying the influence of specific neurotransmitters on the processing of sensory information by specific cerebellar pathways for three reasons: 1) The inferior olive is composed of functionally discrete groups of neurons located in physiologically accessible reeons within the inferior olive (Barmack and Hess.

'Sob; Leonard et al., '88; Barmack et al., '89). 2) It is possible to modulate systematically the discharge of these groups of neurons by parametrically varying the sensory stimuli (see above). 3) The groups of olivary neurons that receive either visual (Barmack and Hess, '80b; Leonard et al., '88) or vestibular (Barmack et al., '89) information project to the cerebellar flocculus (Alley et al., '75) and nodulus (Balaban and Henry, '88; Takeda and Maekawa, '89a).
These cerebellar regions have obvious functional importance for both short-term and long-term control of reflexive movements (Fernandez and Fredrickson, '64; Singleton, '67; Barmack, '79; Ito, '84).
Recently we have studied the distribution of a cholinergic mossy fiber pathway to the cerebellum of several mammals (Barmack et al., '92b).

We have shown that this cholinergic pathway arises predominantly from secondary vestibular neurons whose cell bodies are located bilaterally in the medial vestibular nucleus (MNV) and the descending vestibular nucleus (DVN), as well as the nucleus prepositus hypoglossi (NPH) (Barmack et al., '92c).
In the present experiment we have investigated the cholinergic innervation of the dorsal cap of rat, rabbit and monkey.
In the rat we have traced the origin of this cholinergic projection to the contralateral nucleus prepositus hypoglossi and the medial aspect of the contralateral MVN.
In the rabbit, the cholinergic innervation of the inferior olive is more diffuse and not restricted to the dorsal cap.
In the monkey, like the rat, the cholinergic innervation is restricted to the dorsal cap.
In the rat and rabbit we have used orthograde tracers to demonstrate a projection to the contralateral dorsal cap from the NPH.
In the rat, this projection is cholinergic.
In the rabbit, it probably is not.

A preliminary report of these findings, in which the projection from the NPH to the dorsal cap was incorrectly described as an ipsilateral projection has been published previously (Barmack et al., '91).

Methods.S: METHODS
Fifteen rats, two monkeys, and seven rabbits were used in these experiments.
Some of these animals were also used in previous investigations of the cholinergic innervation of the cerebellum (Barmack et al., '92a-c).
Choline acetyltransferase (ChAT) immunohistochemistry
The protocol for CMT imrnunohistochemistry was similar to that reported previously (Eckenstein et al., '88; Barmack et al., '92c).

A mouse antiserum to rat CUT, Mouse-aRat-CUT, was used to examine the cholinergic projection to the inferior olive of the rat and a rat antiserum to pig CUT, Rat-aPig-ChAT, was used for immunostaining of the inferior olives of rabbits and monkeys.
These antibodies were prepared and characterized previously and have been shown to stain cholinergic neurons specifically (Eckenstein et al., '81: '88).
Deep anesthesia was induced in rats and rabbits with an intramuscular injection of a mixture of ketamine hydrochloride (50 mgikg), xylazine (6 mgikg), and acepromazine maleate (1.2 mgikg).
Anesthesia was induced in monkeys with an intraperitoneal injection of sodium pentobarbital (60 mgikg).
Following the induction of anesthesia, the heart was exposed and the descending aorta was clamped.
A cannula was inserted from the apex of the left ventricle into the dorsal aorta, and the right atrium was opened.
The blood was rinsed with 250-500 ml of saline at 100 cm pressure.
The rinse was followed by perfusion with 500-1,000 ml of 4% paraformaldehyde, 0.159 saturated picric acid, in 0.1 M phosphate buffered saline (PBS), pH = 7.2.
The fixative was given over a period of 30 minutes and was followed by a rinse with cold 0.1 M phosphate buffer (PB), pH = 7.2 (4°C).
The brain was then removed and cryoprotected in lo%), 2094 and 30% sucrose in 0.1 M PB, pH = 7.2.
The brainstem was cut into a block that was attached to thin pieces of cork with embedding compound and then frozen by immersion into isopentane cooled with liquid nitrogen.
Frozen sections (30-40 KM) were cut and collected in cold 0.1 M PB, pH 7.4, in a small plastic grid divided into separate collection baskets with a floor of nylon mesh.

ChAT immunohistochemistry was performed on free floating sections as follows: 1) Sections were washed overnight at room temperature in 0.1 M PR, pH = 7.4. 2) Sections were washed with three 5 minute changes of 0.1 M Tris buffered saline (TBS, 0.1 M Tris, 0.15 M sodium chloride, pH = 7.6) and transferred to 96-well microplate tissue wells with a polished glass rod.
These microplate tissue wells were used for primary antibody, secondary antibody and PAP incubations.
The sections were pretreated at room temperature in a 10%' normal rabbit serum, 2% bovine serum albumin (BSA), 0.5% Triton X-100 in TBS for 2 hours followed by three 10-minute rinses in TBS.

They were gently agitated on an orbital shaker during this and subsequent procedures. 3) Brainstem sections were incubated overnight in the primary antiserum, diluted 1:1,000-1:2,000 in TBS containing 2% BSA, 10% normal rat serum, 0.5% Triton X-100, and 0.1% sodium azide. 4) Sections were transferred to the larger collection baskets and washed with three 10-minute changes of TBS. 5 ) Sections were transferred to the microplate tissue wells and incubated for 60 minutes in freshly prepared rabbit or goat a-mouse or a-rat secondary antibodies (Organon Teknika Gorp., Durham, NC) diluted 1:50 in TBS, containing 2% BSA, 10% rat serum, and 0.2% Triton X-100. 6 ) Sections were transferred to the larger collection baskets and washed in three 10-minute changes of TBS. 7) Sections were then transferred to the microplate tissue wells and incubated for 90 minutes in freshly prepared mouse or rat peroxidaseantiperoxidase (PAP, Sternberger-Meyer Immunocytochemicals, Jnc., Baltimore, MD) diluted 1:50 in TBS. 8) Sections were transferred to the larger collection baskets and washed in three 10-minute changes of TBS. 9) Steps 5-8 were repeated. 10) Sections were treated for 15 minutes with diaminobenzidine (DAB) 1 mgiml in 0.1 M TBS, pH = 7.6, containing 0.01% HzOz.
Sections were then rinsed in 0.1 M PB (pH = 7.41, mounted, dried, cleared, and coverslipped.
The specificities of the primary and secondary antibodies were tested by processing control sections in which these antibodies were omitted.
Orthograde transport of phaseolus leucoagglutinin (PHA-L)
Rats and rabbits were anesthetized with intramuscular injections of ketamine hydrochloride (50 mgikg), xylazine (6 mgikg), and acepromazine maleate (1.2 mgikg).
The brainsterns of both rats and rabbits were exposed by making an opening through the dura mater overlying the cisterna magna.
A micropipette containing a solution of 2.5% PHA-L in 0.1 M PBS (pH = 7.4), was inserted under direct vision into the NPH, MVN, or DVN.
PHA-L was iontophoretically injected into the brainstem by means of 10 FA cathodal pulses lasting 10 seconds, with a 50% duty cycle (Gerfen and Sawchenko, '84; Ter Horst et al., '84).
Each injection lasted 10 minutes.
Several (3-5) injections were made along the medial-lateral and rostral-caudal extent of the brainstem.
After a 3-6 day survival period, the animals were anesthetized (see above) and transcardially perfused.
A brief saline flush was followed by a 4% paraformaldehyde, 0.15% picric acid solution in 0.1 M PBS, pH = 7.2.
The perfusion was terminated, cryoprotected, and frozen sections (30-40 bm) were cut and collected as described above.
A double PAP immunohistochemical procedure, with DAB as the chromagen as described above, was used to identify the presence of orthogradely transported PHA-L.
Retrograde transport of horseradish peroxidase (HRP) and wheat germ agglutinin-HRP (WGA-HRP)
Four pigmented rabbits (weight 0.8-1.7 kg) were anesthetized intravenously with a-chloralose (50 mgikg) and urethane (500 mgikg).
Rectal temperature was also monitored and maintained at 37°C.
The brainstems of the rabbits were exposed by making an opening through the dura mater overlying the cisterna magna.
A micropipette containing a 30% solution of horseradish peroximdase (HRP) or a 3% solution of wheat-germ agglutinin-horseradish peroxidase (WGA-HRPI NaCl was inserted into the brainstem.
The electrode was advanced toward the dorsal cap of the inferior olive.
The characteristic optokinetically evoked activity of the neurons in the caudal aspect of the dorsal cap was used to localize the tip of the microelectrode (Barmack and Hess, 'Sob).
Subsequently, a pressure injection of HRP or WGAHRP (20-100 nl) was made in the dorsal cap over a period of 10 minutes.
Following a 2-3 day postoperative survival, the rabbits were deeply anesthetized with sodium pentobarbital (60 mgikg).

For single label experiments, the rabbits were subsequently perfused transcardially with 0.9% saline, followed by 1.0% paraformaldehyde and 1.25% glutaraldehyde in 0.1 M PBS (pH = 7.4), lasting 20-30 minutes.

For combined ChAT-HRP double-label experiments, rabbits were perfused with 0.9% saline, followed by a fixing solution containing 2.5% paraformaldehyde, 0.15% picric acid, and 0.20% glutaraldehyde in 0.1 M PBS, pH = 7.4.
The perfusions were terminated with a rinse of 0.1 M PBS, pH = 7.4.
The brains were removed and cryoprotected with lo%, 20%, and 30% sucrose in 0.1 M PBS, pH = 7.4.
The brainstem was cut, mounted onto cork with OCT compound, and frozen in isopentane cooled with liquid nitrogen.
Frozen sections (30-40 km) were cut and collected in cold 0.1 M PBS; pH = 7.4.
A DAB-stabilized, CoC12intensified, tetramethylbenzidine (TMB) reaction (Rye et a]., '84; Olucha et al., '85) was used to demonstrate the presence of retrogradely transported tracers.
Lesions of the vestibular complex
Rats were anesthetized (as above) and the brainstems were exposed through the cisterna magna.
A glass micropipette with a tip diameter of approximately 10 km was advanced under direct vision towards different regions of the vestibular complex without penetrating the cerebellum.
A total of 0.3-0.5 kl of ibotenic acid (20-40 kgiml) was injected at three separate sites in the MVN andior NPH.
Alternatively, electrolytic lesions were made in these nuclei (50 PA, 60 seconds, electrode negative).
Electrolytic lesions were made in a triangular pattern more laterally into the medial and descending vestibular nuclei.
After a survival period of 5-7 days the rats were reanesthetized and transcardially perfused (as above).
The brainstem was removed, cryoprotected, and cut on a cryostat.
Sections were processed with a double PAP protocol for ChAT immunohistochemistry as described above.
Histological reconstruction

For each histological procedure involving ChAT immunohistochemistry, orthograde and retrograde tracers, and lesion-induced ChAT depletion, the distribution of labeled cells or tracer injections within the vestibular complex was plotted on maps of the vestibular complex and inferior olive.
The map of the vestibular complex follows the designation ofMeessen and Olszewski ('49).

Results.S: RESULTS
ChAT-immunoreactivity in the dorsal cap of the inferior olive of the rat, rabbit, and monkey
l h e entire caudal-rostra1 extent of the dorsal cap of the caudal-rostra1 extent of the dorsal cap of the ChAT-positive terminals (Fig. 1A).
The CUT-
rat contained ChAT-positive terminals (Fig. 1A).

The CUTpositive immunoreactivity was restricted to the dorsal cap from its most caudal extent to the most rostral aspect where the dorsal cap merges with the principal olive via the ventrolateral outgrowth (Fig. 1A-D).
The ventrolateral outgrowth contained only a few CUT-positive terminals.
No olivary neurons were ChAT-positive.
In the rat, dorsal cap neurons were distributed heterogeneously.
Regions of the dorsal cap were free of neurons and therefore were without ChAT-labeled terminals (Fig. lB-D).
Unlike the cholinergic innervation of the dorsal cap of the rat, the cholinergic innervation of the dorsal cap of the rabbit was difficult to differentiate.
It was composed of fine beaded axonal branches.
These axons were present along the entire caudal asp& of the inferior olive.
A greater concentration of these beaded axonal terminals could be observed in the dorsal cap, but also within the p-nucleus (Fig. 2).
In the monkey, a discrete cholinergic projection was observed throughout the rostral-caudal extent of the dorsal cap.
Figure 3A illustrates the location and extent of ChATpositive terminals in the monkey inferior olive.
These terminals were found in the medial aspect of the dorsal cap at its most rostral extent.
Throughout the remaining rostral-caudal extent of the dorsal cap, the terminals were found in the ventral third of the dorsal cap.
This corresponds to the region of the inferior olive that was retrogradely labeled following HRP injections into the flocculus of the monkey (Langer et al., '85).
The heterogeneous cell distribution within the dorsal cap of the monkey was less apparent than in the rat.
However, in the monkey there were ChAT-positive bands of varying width, alternately spaced with bands of terminals that were not stained (Fig. 3C,D).
In both the rat and monkey no other areas of the inferior olive other than the dorsal cap contained ChAT-positive terminals.

Brainstem projections to the dorsal cap as revealed by the orthograde transport of PHA-L iontophoretically injected into the nucleus prepositus hypoglossi and the medial and descending vestibular nuclei in the rat and rabbit

TTE.S: Iontophoretic injections of PHA-L into the NPH, MVN and DVN resulted in orthograde transport of PHA-L to terminals in the dorsal cap and the beta nucleus.
A large injection into the NPH, MVN and DVN of rat labeled terminals in both the dorsal cap and the p-nucleus (Fig. 4A-C,E).
Some terminals were also labeled in the lateral aspect of the medial accessory olive (Fig. 4B,D).
PHA-L injections restricted to the MVN and the DVN labeled terminals in the p-nucleus without labeling neurons in the dorsal cap (Fig. 5).
However,small iontophoretic injections of PHA-L restricted to the medial aspect of the MVN and lateral aspect of the NPH resulted in labeling of terminals confined to the dorsal cap (Fig. 6).

Results.S: Thus, the evidence from these orthograde tracer experiments suggests that the cholinergic input to the dorsal cap arises from the NPH, with a possible, but lesser contribution from the most medial aspect of the MVN.

TTE.S: Iontophoretic injections of PHA-L into the NPH of the rabbit resulted in orthograde transport of PHA-L to terminals in the dorsal cap that were contralateral to the injection site (Fig 7).
In Figure 7A an experiment is illustrated in which a PHA-L injection was largely restricted to the right NPH.
It was difficult to confine the injection of a midline structure to just one side and a small amount of the PHA-L also diffused into the left NPH (Fig. 7&).
Some of the tracer diffused laterally into the right MVN.
The PHA-L injections labeled axons that descended towards the inferior olive primarily to the right of the midline (Fig. 7B).
These fibers crossed the midline just above the inferior olive to provide a dense innervation of the left dorsal cap (Fig. 7B,C).
This midline crossing point is indicated by an arrow in Fig. 7B.
A less dense innervation could be observed in the right dorsal cap (Fig. 7B).
A sparse innervation of the right p-nucleus and medial accessory olive could be seen as a result of the lateral spread of the injected PHA-L into the right MVN (Fig. 7B).
The projection from the MVN to the olive was predominantly ipsilateral.

Results.S: Brainstem projections to the dorsal cap as revealed by the retrograde transport of WGA-HRP injected in the dorsal cap of the inferior olive of the rabbit

TTE.S: In two rabbits a 3% solution of WGA-HRP (20-50 nl) was pressure injected into the caudal dorsal cap.

This injection labeled two major sources of afferents to the dorsal cap: 1) the ipsilateral nucleus of the optic tract, the source of visual directionally specific input to the caudal dorsal cap; and 2) The contralateral nucleus prepositus hypoglossi (NPH).
The retrograde labeling of cells in the lateral aspect of the NPH is illustrated in Figure 8.
The schematic illustration in Figure 8A maps the distribution oflabeled neurons withinthe NPH.
This distribution extends slightly into the medial aspect of the MVN (Fig. 8A).

Results.S: ChATand HRP-labeled neurons in the nucleus prepositus hypoglossi (NPH) following pressure injections of HRP into the dorsal cap of the rabbit

TTE.S: In one rabbit HRP (100 nl) was injected into the caudal inferior olive.
The injection site was large.
It included both the right dorsal cap and right p-nucleus.
Smaller amounts of the injected HRP also labeled the left dorsal cap and left p-nucleus (Fig. 9A).
Retrograde labeling of cells in the ipsilateral MVN and DVN as well as both the ipsilateral and contralateral NPH was observed (Fig. 9).
Retrograde labeling in the ipsilateral MVN was observed more caudally (Fig. 9C4,5).
Retrograde labeling in the ipsilateral DVN was observed more rostrally (Fig. 9C1-3).
In agreement with a previous investigation, ChA'l'-labeled neurons in the vestibular complex were observed primarily in the caudal aspect of the MVN (Barmack et al., '92c).

While the HRP injection in this experiment was too large to permit conclusion concerning the ipsilateral or contralateral origins of the projection to the inferior olive from the vestibular complex, it did permit us to determine whether any of the projection from the NPH to the dorsal cap was cholinergic.
A total of only two cells in the NPH were double labeled for both ChAT and HRP.
None of the HRP-labeled cells in the right MVN, DVN, and NPH was also labeled for ChAT.

These data agree with the relative paucity of the ChAT innervation of the dorsal cap in the rabbit and suggest that the projection to the dorsal cap from the contralateral NPH and the projection to the p-nucleus from the ipsilateral MVN and DVN must be mediated by another transmitter.

Results.S: Degeneration of the cholinergic projection to the dorsal cap caused by lesions of the nucleus prepositus hypoglossi and medial vestibular nucleus in the rat
Unilateral pressure injections of ibotenic acid or electrolytic lesions were made in the region of the NPH and MVN in four rats (Fig. 10).
Figure 10A indicates the extent of an ibotenic acid lesion in the NPH and MVN in one of these rats.
The black area indicates the complete absence of neurons while the shaded area indicates partial cell loss.
Most of the NPH was destroyed while only a small portion of the MVN was affected.
This lesion resulted in reduced ChAT-immunoreactivity ipsilateral to the lesion (Fig.
IOC).
This decrease in ChAT positive terminals within the dorsal cap was observed only if a lesion encroached upon the NPH.

In two rats, electrolytic lesions restricted to the lateral aspect of the MVN and the medial aspect of the DVN caused no detectable loss of ChAT-positive immunoreactivity in the ipsilatcral dorsal cap.

Discussion.S: DISCUSSION
the cholinergic projection to the dorsal cap
The immunohistochemical findings of the present experiment demonstrate a discrete cholinergic projection to the dorsal cap in the inferior olive of both the rat and monkey.
In the rat the region of cholinergc innervation corresponds to a subset of olivary neurons that project to the flocculus (Blanks et al., '83; Ruigrok et al., '92).
However the ventrolateral outgrowth also projects to the flocculus, but received only a small cholinergic input (Ruigrok et al., '92).
In the rabbit, there is a weak and diffuse cholinergic innervation of the entire caudal aspect of the inferior olive, including the dorsal cap and p-nucleus (Fig. 2).
Interestingly, both the rat and monkey have a well defined cholinerpic projection to the uvula-nodulus of the cerebellum originating from the caudal aspect of the MVN (Barmack et al., '92b,c).
In the rabbit, there is only a weak cholinergc projection to these same regions, although there is a very strong cholinergic innervation of the ventral paraflocculus (Barmack et al., '92b:c).

The origin of the cholinergic projection from the NPH in the rat was supported by both the orthograde transport of PHA-L (Figs. 5,6) and by the reduction of ChAT staining in the contralateral dorsal cap following subtotal unilateral lesions placed in the NPH and MVN (Fig. 10).

In the rabbit, although both orthograde and retrograde transport experiments revealed a projection from the NPH to the contralateral dorsal cap (Figs. 7-91, both the paucity of ChAT labeling of terminals within the dorsal cap and the lack of HRP retrograde labeling of ChAT-positive neurons within the NPH suggested that this projection is not cholinergic (Figs. 7-9).

The projection from the NPH to the contralateral dorsal cap of both rat and rabbit agrees with previous anatomical studies, using orthograde tracers, that demonstrated this same projection in cat (Gerrits et al., '85; McCrea and Baker, '85).
Co-expression of acetylcholine and GABA in NPH neurons?
It seems reasonable to conclude that in the rabbit the NPH projection to the contralateral dorsal cap is mediated primarily by a non-cholinergic transmitter system.
A likely alternative transmitter is GABA.
In the rabbit, there is a dense GABAergic innervation of the dorsal cap as revealed by immunohistochemical staining for glutamic acid decarboxylase (GAD) (Nelson et al., '89).
Recently, it has been shown that the NPH projection to the contralateral dorsal cap of the rabbit is at least in part GABAergic (De Zeeuw et al., '92).
This raises the interesting possibility that the same anatomical projection in the rat and rabbit is mediated by two different neurotransmitters: acetylcholine in the rat and GABA in the rabbit.
However, it is possible that both transmitters are co-expressed in NPH neurons in both species.
Such co-expression of acetylcholine and GABA has been described in amacrine cells of the retina (O'Malley et al., '92).

Therefore it is possible that the weak ChAT staining of fiber terminals in the dorsal cap of the rabbit and the apparent lack of double-labeled cells in the NPH reflects a low expression of ChAT in NPH neurons in the rabbit.
The question of co-expression of acetylcholine and GABA by NPH neurons could be addressed directly in the rat by the use of markers for both ChAT and GAD.
Vestibular projections to the p-nucleus
Previous retrograde transport studies in the rat and rabbit demonstrated that the medial aspect of the DVN gives rise to a GABAergic projection to the p-nucleus (Nelson et al., '86, '89).
These results are confirmed by the present retrograde transport studies in the rabbit (Fig. 9) and further supported by the orthograde transport of PHA-L in both rat and rabbit (Figs. 4, 5, 7).
The present results suggest that there is also a vestibular projection to the p-nucleus that originates from the caudal and lateral aspect of the MVN.
However, we do not know if this MVN projection to the p-nucleus is GABAergic.
Receptors for the cholinergic and GABAergic inputs to the inferior olive
Presently the cholinergic receptors on olivary neurons are not well characterized.
However, we have obtained preliminary immunohistochemical evidence in both rat and rabbit for the presence of the M2 subclass of muscarinic receptors (Barmack, unpublished observations).

In the cerebellum there is both pharmacological and irnmunological evidence that indicates that there are M2 receptors on granule cells, the cells that receive the cholinergic innervation from the vestibular complex (Giraldo et al., '87; Ehlert and Tran, '90; Fukamauchi et al., '91; Li et al., '91).
In other systems, M2 receptors are coupled via a pertussis toxin-sensitive G protein to a potassium conductance (Ito et al., '91; Lai et al., '91; Richards, '91; Bonner, '92).
Functionally, this means that activation of M2 receptors hyperpularizes the neurons on which they are located, by driving the membrane potential towards the potassium equilibrium potential.

If the same transduction mechanism is found for the M2 receptors on dorsal cap neurons, then it is possible that the optokinetic sensitivity of dorsal cap neurons contralateral to the NPH could be reduced by the activation of the NPH cholinergic neurons.
Presently, the distribution of GABAergic receptor subtypes within the inferior olive is not known.
In the rabbit inferior olive, it is possible that the GAEiAergic projection to the dorsal cap would have the same inhibitory effect as would the cholinergic projection in the rat.

Namely, if dorsal cap neurons expressed GABAA receptors similar in subunit composition to the GABAA receptors expressed on cerebellar granule cells, the GABAergic pathway from NPH to the dorsal cap could be functionally inhibitory since GABAA receptors are coupled to a chloride conductance (Engblom et al., '89).
The cholinergic projection would be functionally inhibitory, coupled by an M2 receptor through a G protein to a potassium conductance.
Functional importance of the cholinergic projection to the dorsal cap

The dorsal cap has been implicated functionally in an optokinetic circuit that projects to both the flocculus and nodulus (Maekawa and Simpson, '73; Alley et al., '75; Graf et al., '88; Leonard et al., '88; Barmack and Shojaku, '89, '92; Takeda and Maekawa, '89b).

This circuitry when activated by optokinetic stimulation of the contralateral eye in the posterior-anterior direction (Barmack, '79; Barmack and Hess, 'Sob; Barmack and Simpson, '80) evokes conjugate eye movements that have a slow phase in the same direction as the optokinetic stimulus.
These optokinetically evoked eye movements null the retinal slip caused by the optokinetic stimulus and consequently reduce the evoked activity in the contralateral dorsal cap.
Microstimulation of the dorsal cap, in the absence of visual feedback, evokes eye movements whose slow phase is towards the stimulated dorsal cap (Barmack and Hess, '80a).
Optokinetic stimulation of the left eye in the posterior-anterior direction evokes activity in the right dorsal cap.
This activity evokes an increase in climbing fiber responses and a decrease in simple spike responses in both the left nodulus and flocculus.

This reduction in simple spike activity of the left flocculus and nodulus reduces Purkinje cell inhibition of the left vestibular complex, thereby evoking compensatory eye movements in the rightward direction (Barmack and Pettorossi, '81).
This horizontal optokinetic reflex is impaired by a unilateral lesion of the left flocculus without reducing the gain of the horizontal vestibuloocular reflex (Barmack and Pettorossi, '85).

Eye movements evoked by either optokinetic stimulation or by electrical stimulation of the dorsal cap can also outlast the natural or electrical stimulus, leading to an afternystagmus (Barmack, '79; Barmack and Hess, '80a; Barmack and Nelson, '87).
The cholinergic pathway to the dorsal cap from the NPH and the medial aspect of the MVN could provide a more centralized control of visual information mediated by the dorsal cap.

The signal that originates from the NPH includes vestibular and eye movement-related information (Blanks et al., '77; Lopez-Barneo et al., '82) rather than the purely optokinetic information that originates from the nucleus of the optic tract.

In the monkey, the signal from neurons in the NPH appears to represent eye position exclusively since NPH neurons are not modulated by either vestibular or optokinetic stimulation when a monkey is trained to maintain fixation during such stimulation (McFarland and Fuchs, '92).

It is possible that a better understanding of the importance of this pathway will be revealed by both micropharmacological experiments that further delineate the specific receptor subtypes present on dorsal cap neurons and by behavioral experiments in which it is possible to specify and control the activity of NPH neurons that project to the contralateral dorsal cap.
